tag_narrative: SDG 16: Peace and Justice Strong Institutions
title_narrative: Humanitarian Mine Action response in North East Syria
sector_narrative: Removal of land mines and explosive remnants of war
description_narrative: Contract related to: Humanitarian Mine Action response in North East Syria - As the conflict in Syria has entered its eleventh year, the living conditions of ordinary Syrians have worsened dramatically as a result of continued hostilities, deteriorating socio-economic conditions, and the external repercussions of the Russian war of aggression against Ukraine. In the North-East, human security in communities and existing camps is further deteriorating, with the recent and recurrent attacks on security forces and civilians recalling the risk of resurgence of DaÂ¿esh. In this context, additional stabilisation efforts are needed to minimise the risk of any further radicalisation and recruitment by extremist groups, which remains a major threat, especially for vulnerable children and youth. This measure will promote safer access to protection and learning spaces for children and boys at risk of further radicalisation and recruitment. It will also strengthen the social and economic resilience of host communities, internally displaced persons, and returnees in an effort to address urgent and longer-term needs. Finally, it will ensure that land mines and explosive remnants of war are removed from community infrastructure to ensure safer access to community services for the target populations in urban and rural areas.
result_title_narrative: Humanitarian/development/peacebuilding programs in North East Syria (NES) take place unencumbered by landmines, ERWs and IEDs.
Outcome 1: The Humanitarian Mine Action (HMA) response and Explosive Ordnance (EO) contamination knowledge is strengthened, coordinated and the implementation of operations facilitated.
Output 2: A Mine Action Information Management system is centralized amongst all actors, to generate exhaustive and evidencebased products with humanitarian and stabilization organizations.
Output 1: HMA activities are coordinated and prioritized within Mine Action actors.
Output 1: HMA activities are coordinated and prioritized within Mine Action actors.
Outcome 2: Clearance activities in NES are prioritized on evidencebased information collected by iMMAP and its partners.
Output 3: Humanitarian and stabilization organizations operating in NES are informed about Explosive Ordnance contamination and assisted to mitigate inherent threats.
2.1 The level of EO contamination  is better known at a regional level and reported.
2.2 Gender balanced NonTechnical Survey teams are recruited and trained to implement the general contamination survey.
2.3 The general contamination survey methodology is coordinated, and Information Management system standardized amongst 3 co applicants.

result_description_narrative: This project supports the decision makings of stakeholders operating in NES, by providing evidencebased and datadriven analysis

Outcome 1: The Humanitarian Mine Action (HMA) response and Explosive Ordnance (EO) contamination knowledge is strengthened, coordinated and the implementation of operations facilitated. The HMA response is NES is strengthened by facilitating a formal sector coordination and improving the management of EO related data, its analysis and dissemination

Output 2: A Mine Action Information Management system is centralized amongst all actors, to generate exhaustive and evidencebased products with humanitarian and stabilization organizations. iMMAP France collects, checks, consolidates and processes data from all HMA actors to generate products that are essential for the conduct of evidencebased programmings.
iMMAP leads the Mine Action Sub Working group in NES to facilitate a more accountable and effective Mine Action response
iMMAP leads the Mine Action Sub Working group in NES to facilitate a more accountable and effective Mine Action response
International and local humanitarian/stabilization stakeholders are prioritizing clearance efforts based on the results of the NES wide Nontechnical Survey.

iMMAP France actively coordinates with other sectors and set up online tools accessible to all NGOs in NES to be informed about EO threats. Organizations and donors can also address Mine Action need requests (production of maps, analysis..) to iMMAP France.

The nature, impact and location of suspected/confirmed EO contamination  is known and reported in the whole NES region following a systematic and general Non Technical Survey (NTS). Reported SHAs/CHAs and EO evidence point will be prioritized to optimize further clearance efforts.
2.2 Gender balanced NonTechnical Survey teams are recruited and trained to implement the general contamination survey.2 members will compose a team (one female and one male)
iMMAP France coordinates the planning and methodology of the contamination Survey and develops an online and standardized Information Management system.
iMMAP leads the Mine Action Sub Working group in NES to facilitate a more accountable and effective Mine Action response
This project supports the decision makings of stakeholders operating in NES, by providing evidencebased and datadriven analysis

result_indicator_period_actual_comment_n: One victims gender could not be determined when reporting the accident.
Mid term survey shared to stakeholders receiving the actions products.

The report was shared through 2 different dissemination channels. As such it was first presented during the VII Brussels Conference and shared with all participants. It was further shared by emails to 101ckey stakeholders amongst donors NGO forum partners Whole of Syria coordination partners and ad hoc Mine Action specialists.The report was shared via a link to the reliefweb website to ensure that individuals not part of the mailing list can also find it online.

3 MASGW partners focal points failed to respond to the survey despite numerous reminders many focal points on leaves during this period. Thus this result reflects the views of only half partners.  For the endline survey iMMAP France will combine the methodology with individual meetings to ensure all partners feedback are collected. The survey will also be maintained as it is anonymous and encourage more transparent and uninfluenced answers. Out of 3 responders 2 assessed that the MASGW coordination is facilitating their programs implementation and that this mechanism is recommended. 1 partner answered that such platform was partially helpful only. After discussion this partner is mostly frustrated by the lack of additional endorsement iMMAP France should receive to act as an authority instead of the NESMAO as UNMAS can be mandated in certain context. All feedback collected through this survey will be analyzed by the team presented to the MASGW partners and follow up actions drafted in a 6month plan. Calculation methodology  Really helpful  5  Helpful  4  Partially helpful  2.5   not helpful  0. Final score  10.5 15

The MASWG gathers all international Mine Action organizations on a monthly basis.  No MASWG meeting could be held in October 2022 as the projects launch was delayed by one month due to a delayed receipt of the grant agreement. Similarly no MASWG was held in September 2023 as partners cancelled it several times due to their internal agendas challenges were raised during this month to engaged actors. In parallel iMMAP France through this action launched an additional operational meeting to empower the NES Mine Action authorities and improve its coordination with international and national Mine Action organizations. One meeting was conducted in July 2023 and added to this result.

iMMAP is receiving from various stakeholders engaged in NES donors NGOs NGO forum information requests related to Mine Action activities. As of September 2023 31 formal requests have been received and addressed so far. For instance during the month of April 23 Save the Children requested information on Explosive Ordnance victims and accidents in order to adapt their protection programming. More recently the organization Blumont asked iMMAP France for support to design and print maps.
Training participants listTraining plan and support
Workshop meeting minutesList of participantsNTS workflow

3 MASGW partners focal points failed to respond to the survey despite numerous reminders many focal points on leaves during this period. Thus this result reflects the views of only half partners.  For the endline survey iMMAP France will combine the methodology with individual meetings to ensure all partners feedback are collected. The survey will also be maintained as it is anonymous and encourage more transparent and uninfluenced answers. Out of 3 responders 2 assessed that the MASGW coordination is facilitating their programs implementation and that this mechanism is recommended. 1 partner answered that such platform was partially helpful only. After discussion this partner is mostly frustrated by the lack of additional endorsement iMMAP France should receive to act as an authority instead of the NESMAO as UNMAS can be mandated in certain context. All feedback collected through this survey will be analyzed by the team presented to the MASGW partners and follow up actions drafted in a 6month plan. The MASWG gathers all international Mine Action organizations on a monthly basis.  No MASWG meeting could be held in October 2022 as the projects launch was delayed by one month due to a delayed receipt of the grant agreement. Similarly no MASWG was held in September 2023 as partners cancelled it several times due to their internal agendas challenges were raised during this month to engaged actors. In parallel iMMAP France through this action launched an additional operational meeting to empower the NES Mine Action authorities and improve its coordination with international and national Mine Action organizations. One meeting was conducted in July 2023 and added to this result.

The report was shared through 2 different dissemination channels. As such it was first presented during the VII Brussels Conference and shared with all participants. It was further shared by emails to 101ckey stakeholders amongst donors NGO forum partners Whole of Syria coordination partners and ad hoc Mine Action specialists.The report was shared via a link to the reliefweb website to ensure that individuals not part of the mailing list can also find it online.

iMMAP is receiving from various stakeholders engaged in NES donors NGOs NGO forum information requests related to Mine Action activities. As of September 2023 31 formal requests have been received and addressed so far. For instance during the month of April 23 Save the Children requested information on Explosive Ordnance victims and accidents in order to adapt their protection programming. More recently the organization Blumont asked iMMAP France for support to design and print maps.

Mid term survey shared to stakeholders receiving the actions products.

3 MASGW partners focal points failed to respond to the survey despite numerous reminders many focal points on leaves during this period. Thus this result reflects the views of only half partners.  For the endline survey iMMAP France will combine the methodology with individual meetings to ensure all partners feedback are collected. The survey will also be maintained as it is anonymous and encourage more transparent and uninfluenced answers. Out of 3 responders 2 assessed that the MASGW coordination is facilitating their programs implementation and that this mechanism is recommended. 1 partner answered that such platform was partially helpful only. After discussion this partner is mostly frustrated by the lack of additional endorsement iMMAP France should receive to act as an authority instead of the NESMAO as UNMAS can be mandated in certain context. All feedback collected through this survey will be analyzed by the team presented to the MASGW partners and follow up actions drafted in a 6month plan. Calculation methodology  Really helpful  5  Helpful  4  Partially helpful  2.5   not helpful  0. Final score  10.5 15

The MASWG gathers all international Mine Action organizations on a monthly basis.  No MASWG meeting could be held in October 2022 as the projects launch was delayed by one month due to a delayed receipt of the grant agreement. Similarly no MASWG was held in September 2023 as partners cancelled it several times due to their internal agendas challenges were raised during this month to engaged actors. In parallel iMMAP France through this action launched an additional operational meeting to empower the NES Mine Action authorities and improve its coordination with international and national Mine Action organizations. One meeting was conducted in July 2023 and added to this result.
Training participants listTraining plan and support

The report was shared through 2 different dissemination channels. As such it was first presented during the VII Brussels Conference and shared with all participants. It was further shared by emails to 101ckey stakeholders amongst donors NGO forum partners Whole of Syria coordination partners and ad hoc Mine Action specialists.The report was shared via a link to the reliefweb website to ensure that individuals not part of the mailing list can also find it online.

iMMAP is receiving from various stakeholders engaged in NES donors NGOs NGO forum information requests related to Mine Action activities. As of September 2023 31 formal requests have been received and addressed so far. For instance during the month of April 23 Save the Children requested information on Explosive Ordnance victims and accidents in order to adapt their protection programming. More recently the organization Blumont asked iMMAP France for support to design and print maps.

result_indicator_period_target_comment_n: as of March 23 2057 victims were reported through the conduct of victim and accident reports by Mine Action organizations. As of this date iMMAP France estimated through open sources that 3036 persons were supposedly victims of EO explosions since 2016 in NES gap of 979 victims not verified through reports. The NESwide NTS will support in collecting additional verified information and improve knowledge decreasing knowledge gaps between opensource database and verified database from Mine Action organizations.
At least 70 of Key stakeholders including HMA actors national and local report improved knowledge about the Mine Action response in NES supporting strategic decisions.

of distinct series of biannual Mine Action reports developed and distributed. This series of reports outlines the level of EO contamination in NES and its impact Mine Action activities progress key challenges and evidencebased recommendations.
Humanitarian Mine Action Organizations participants international and national report having benefited from the MASGW coordination meetings and adhoc meetings hosted by iMMAP.
iMMAP leads formal Mine Action Sub Working Group MASWG monthly coordination meetings with HMA implementing partners.
At least 70 of key stakeholders national and local report improved knowledge about the level of contamination in NES following the general contamination supporting strategic decisions.

of Mine Action assistance reports produced in response to requests. Organizations donors or other stakeholders engaged in the NES humanitarian response can send assistance requests to iMMAP to obtain specific information related to the Mine Action sector in NES production of contamination maps analysis specific reports on victims etc.

Following the general contamination survey NTS implemented by coapplicants a report will be developed and disseminated highlighting the level of contamination reported and a proposed prioritization strategy or plan for future clearance programs.

ITF DCA and HI co applicants will be responsible for recruiting and training a total of 60 surveyors NTS agents. iMMAP France will be responsible for complementing with an Information Management training to ensure data is standardized.
of coordination meetings led by iMMAP France with implementing partners to plan and define the general contamination survey methodology and Information Management needs.
